item.title: üìì What set this value?
item.description: Ever wanted to know what value a variable has and where it was set from in Vim?

item.title: ‚òÅÔ∏è Hosting GOV.UK prototypes
item.description: Whenever I have used the GOV.UK Prototype Kit to build a prototype I have always hosted it on Heroku. The main reason for doing this was because it was just so easy (I wrote a post about just how easy it was many years ago), it was also the default approach - until recently.

item.title: üìì Access env vars in Neovim
item.description: Accessing an environment variable within Neovim from a lua script is straight forward. It is just a case of calling vim.env.env-var-name where env-var-name is the name of the environment variable e.g.

item.title: üêô Custom email routing per organization in GitHub
item.description: Within GitHub, if you belong to multiple organisations it is easy to have those notifications routed to specific email addresses. This is very useful if, for example, you use the same GitHub account for work and personal use.

item.title: üî® Fix missing module error
item.description: Within a Svelte project seeing an error such as cannot find module '$lib/..' or its corresponding type declarations can be resolved by running npm run prepare. This will update tsconfig.json to add $lib to compilerOptions.paths.

item.title: üìö Using Architectural Decision Records
item.description: Decisions are made all of the time when developing software. Some decisions are small and easy to change such as the name of a variable or whether to extract some code into a separate class/function/module. Other decisions are larger and more difficult to change such as which test framework to use, whether to use JSON or XML or if a NoSQL database should be used in favour of a SQL database, etc.

item.title: ü™Ö Build, create and start named services from Docker Compose
item.description: It is possible to build, create, start and up a specific service or services from Docker Compose. By default these commands work with an optional list of services. Each service specified will have the command run for it.

item.title: üìì Docker Compose version key is not required after 3.7
item.description: From version 3.8 of the compose file specification the version key is no longer required. However, it can be kept for information, if so desired.

item.title: ‚ÜïÔ∏è Ordering content
item.description: It is straight forward to order content in Hugo by leveraging front matter variables. The default order is Weight -> Date -> LinkTitle -> FilePath. It is easy to change the order based on the specific property of interest. See lists of content in Hugo for more information.

item.title: üìì Interacting with vim's dictionary
item.description:
Add a misspelt word to Vim’s dictionary with zg.

See the list of suggestions for a misspelt word with z=. Enter the number of the correct suggestion and hit enter to select it.

item.title: üì¢ Keep a brag document
item.description: Over the years I’ve tried to keep a record of what I’ve done in some form or other. I’ve experimented with week notes (effectively a summary of what you did over the past week that you might make public, or just keep private).

item.title: üìì Get last Git commit message
item.description: In a Git repo run git log -1 to get details of the last commit.

item.title: üêö Useful bash builtins
item.description: A subset of Bash builtins I occasionally forget about and want a quick reference to.

item.title: üîç Search hidden files with ripgrep
item.description: ripgrep is an excellent alternative to grep. One of its benefits is how it filters the files it searches.

item.title: üêö Source and export all vars from a file
item.description: If you ever need to load a bunch of env vars into an environment it is easily accomplished by having them listed in a .env file e.g.

item.title: üóìÔ∏è Daily updates
item.description: Teams often have a daily catch-up, often referred to as a stand-up, where an update is provided by each member of the team. The standard approach to the daily updates is a 15 minute meeting where participants answer three questions:

item.title: üîä Communicating changes in PRs
item.description: When asking for a review of a pull request (PR) ensure there is suitable context provided to the reviewer(s).

item.title: üñ•Ô∏è App specific domain names for local dev
item.description: A common architectural style (at the time of writing) is to split up applications into many, smaller, more focussed applications. Frequently this style is known by the term microservices. When working with microservices I’ve rarely had the need to run, and actually use, more than a single web application concurrently in my development environment.

item.title: üí≠ General working principles
item.description: Following on from the post about development practices and principles I wanted to capture principles more related to general ways of thinking and working. As before, this isn’t in any particular order.

item.title: ‚ú® Development practices and principles
item.description: During my time working in software development I’ve picked up a few guiding principles I try to consistently follow. Some of them have always been the way I’ve tried to work and others have been adopted after having been burnt by not using it in the first place or learning better ways of doing and thinking about things.

item.title: üî¨ When to Use Microservices (And When Not to!)
item.description: I watched When To Use Microservices (And When Not to!) soon after it was published but never got round to publishing this post, which I wrote at the same time but have edited more recently so I could publish it. The post contains some thoughts I had about the video and thought it would be worth capturing them and maybe try to get back into blogging at some regular interval, although clearly that didn’t happen at the time…

item.title: üè¶ Use personal Slack for GitHub notifications
item.description: GitHub is a pretty decent cloud based Git repository. I would put it in my top 2 along with GitLab.

item.title: üéâ TeamCity Pipeline - iteration two
item.description: Now I have had the TeamCity build pipeline running for a while I have had chance to review how it works. I have made a number of changes which I have summarised, along with the reasoning below.

item.title: üéã Create branch based NuGet packages in TeamCity
item.description: As I was reviewing the TeamCity build configuration I’d setup with my colleagues, it was pointed out every build was creating a new NuGet package. Not great when you consider every branch was triggering a build and most of those branches were not master.

item.title: üî® DIY Git remotes
item.description:
Working with a non-cloud hosted Git remote

I often work in environments where the code is centrally stored in TFS. And as I hate, HATE, HATE TFS I have to find other ways to interact with the VCS to keep my sanity. GitTFS to the rescue. I’ve written about this before.

item.title: „ÄΩÔ∏è Git aliases
item.description: In order to provide a consistent development environment between team members as well as making it easier to do physical pair programming sharing a .gitconfig is a good thing to do. After all, when using another person’s machine there are few things more annoying than not having access to the same shortcuts you rely on.

item.title: üéÅ TeamCity Build Pipeline
item.description: It has been a while since I setup a build configuration in TeamCity. I thought I would record what I did this time around.

item.title: ü§î How I work with Git
item.description: I really enjoy introducing people to Git. Pretty much without fail they see how much better their development work-flow can be and find their work more enjoyable as a result. This is especially true if they are coming from a TFS background. See how I work with Git and TFS. However, with pleasure comes pain. For Git, that pain is in getting over the learning curve. The size and steepness of the curve varies depending on previous experience of Version Control Systems. In my experience, TFS does not provide a good base knowledge to work from as it tries to hide as much as possible from the user. Clearly Git is doing a lot for you too but the way it works is more exposed. For example, even the most basic of things like adding files into the index can seem strange to a TFS user.

item.title: üìâ What lessons should one learn from the Gliffy outage?
item.description: Ever since the recent lengthy and complete outage of Gliffy, I have been thinking about how I could (should that be a should?) protect myself when working with SaaS. Everything is sorted now and Gliffy have a post explaining a bit more detail on the outage. One of the takeaways from that being disaster recovery plans should probably be practiced more often.

item.title: üë∫ Interesting articles (week one)
item.description: I was recently asked to provide a link to an article that had resonated with me in the recent past. The first thing I did was provide a link to my twitter account to that person. Thinking (hoping) the question would be answered. The second thing I did was to go through some of my time line to see what articles I had tweeted about. One of the things I found was I didn’t tweet all that often about articles I find align well to how I think. There are some but there is a lot of stuff I read and do nothing with. There are even fewer tweets about things I don’t feel align well with me which is probably a good thing!

item.title: üòï How I work with Git and TFS
item.description: This post has been one I’ve been meaning to write for months and months. Finally, I’ve got round to it! This does mean specifics are going to be few and far between…

item.title: „Ä∞Ô∏è How to setup a simple Heroku pipeline
item.description: Pipelines in Heroku are pretty awesome. This is how I went about setting up a Node.js app to have automated deployments for all pull requests, an automated deployment to the staging environment and a manual stage for promoting to the production environment. Pretty much a bread and butter pipeline. (This is an image heavy post)

item.title: ‚öíÔ∏è Hack day lite
item.description: This is a post I have been sat on for some time. In fact the date of the day in question was 01/02/2016 so some details are going to be a little inaccurate but hopefully the essence is maintained.

item.title: üìá Tips for using Trello
item.description: The team I work in uses Trello to visualise our work. Some of the team have been using similar tools in order to facilitate work visualisation for several years. Other members are much newer to the concept. Recently the team had a refresher session to bring everybody up to a similar level of understanding.

item.description: How do you generate attributes for html elements that have a dash (-) in them through a C# view template engine while using object initialiser syntax?

item.title: üî¢ Do not use include near in count queries
item.description: Using MongoDB to build an API providing some search and filtering functionality. One of the searches was using the $near query. As part of the call the total number of documents matching the query also needed to be returned.

item.title: üìà Cumulative flow diagrams
item.description:
What is a CFD?

A CFD is a graph showing the state of the work over a period of time based on data acquired from Kanban.
